page.title: 01STOUGHTON AND KINGLEY VALE
page.content: Stroughton is a typical Sussex village with flint walled cottages. The rolling valleys surrounding it are partly grazed by sheep and cattle, and are partly sown to wheat. The golden fields are a feature of the landscape in late summer, and the woods are full of flaming beeches. But by far the largest part of the area is taken up by Kingley Vale National Nature Reserve, which contains the finest yew forest in Europe. Some of the yews are 500 years old, and legend has it that a grove yew trees was planted here to commemorate a battle fought and won in Kingley Vale against marauding Vikings in AD 859. The highest point of Kingley Vale is Bow Hill where there are four Bronze Age burial tombs or barrows, often called the Devils Humps. There is also the famous Tansley Stone. On clear days you can
